title: Backlog Refinement & Prioritization
description: Apply prioritization frameworks (MoSCoW, WSJF, Kano) to sequence backlog work based on value, risk, dependencies, and stakeholder needs.
objectives: Apply MoSCoW method to categorize backlog items into Must-have, Should-have, Could-have, Won't-have
Calculate WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First) scores to prioritize work by cost of delay and job size
Use Kano Model to distinguish Basic Needs (expected), Performance Needs (satisfaction grows linearly), and Delighters (unexpected value)
Facilitate backlog refinement sessions to break down epics, clarify requirements, and update estimates
Balance value delivery, risk mitigation, and technical dependencies when sequencing work
Recognize when to prioritize high-risk items EARLY vs high-value items LATE (risk reduction vs value maximization)

screens.headline: 60 user stories. 12 weeks until launch. Carlos: 'Build everything!' Morgan: 'That's impossible.' Alex: 'Let's prioritize using data, not opinions.'

items.title: Unsorted Backlog
items.description: 60 sticky notes in chaos—Carlos pointing at all of them demanding 'must-have', Morgan overwhelmed

items.title: Prioritized Backlog
items.description: Morgan with MoSCoW categories, WSJF scores, and Kano model matrix bringing order to chaos

dialogue.text: When everything is a priority, nothing is a priority. We have 60 stories and 12 weeks—we can deliver maybe 30 stories max. I need a framework to defend my prioritization decisions to Carlos.

screens.learningHook: Your job: Apply MoSCoW, WSJF, and Kano Model to prioritize 4 competing features, balance value and risk, and coach Morgan on defending prioritization to demanding stakeholders.

screens.title: Prioritization Framework Application
screens.instructions: Apply prioritization frameworks to 4 competing features and make sequencing decisions.

scenarios.title: Scenario 1: MoSCoW Categorization
description: Sprint Planning 3 weeks before launch. Morgan has 8 features remaining. Team velocity = 20 points/sprint. Capacity = 60 points across 3 sprints.
Feature A: Credit card payment (20 pts) - Can't launch without it
Feature B: Gift card payment (8 pts) - Nice to have but not critical
Feature C: Search by dish name (5 pts) - Important for usability
Feature D: Social sharing (13 pts) - Marketing wants it
Feature E: Order history (8 pts) - Customers expect this
Feature F: Dietary filter (5 pts) - Health-conscious customers need this
Feature G: Dark mode (3 pts) - Modern UX standard
Feature H: Recipe details (8 pts) - Interesting but not essential
Total: 70 points > 60 capacity

questions.question: Categorize each feature using MoSCoW (Must-have, Should-have, Could-have, Won't-have for this release):

items.name: Search by dish name (5 pts)
items.reasoning: Critical for usability—customers can't find items without search

items.name: Order history (8 pts)
items.reasoning: Customers expect to see past orders—basic functionality

items.name: Dietary filter (5 pts)
items.reasoning: Important for health-conscious segment but can launch without it

items.name: Dark mode (3 pts)
items.reasoning: Modern UX standard, enhances experience but not launch-blocker

items.name: Gift card payment (8 pts)
items.reasoning: Nice to have, can be added post-launch

items.name: Recipe details (8 pts)
items.reasoning: Interesting content but not essential for ordering

items.name: Social sharing (13 pts)
items.reasoning: Marketing wants it but too costly (13 pts) for uncertain ROI—defer to v2

feedback.correct: Perfect MoSCoW categorization! Must = 38 pts (A+C+E), Should = 8 pts (F+G), Could = 16 pts (B+H), Won't = 13 pts (D). Total committed: 46 pts < 60 capacity. You have buffer for unknowns.
feedback.incorrect: Check your categories. Must-haves are launch blockers (can't go live without them). Should-haves enhance experience but aren't blockers. Could-haves are nice extras. Won't-haves are deferred to future releases.

scenarios.title: Scenario 2: WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First) Prioritization
description: Morgan needs to prioritize 3 features for Sprint 1. All are valuable, but which delivers best ROI (value/cost)?
Feature X: Loyalty Points Redemption
- User-Business Value: 8/10 (high revenue impact)
- Time Criticality: 3/10 (can wait)
- Risk Reduction: 2/10 (low technical risk)
- Job Size: 13 story points
Feature Y: Order Tracking (real-time status)
- User-Business Value: 5/10 (moderate value)
- Time Criticality: 8/10 (launch commitment to customers)
- Risk Reduction: 7/10 (high technical risk—integration with delivery API)
- Job Size: 8 story points
Feature Z: Promo Code Application
- User-Business Value: 7/10 (drives conversions)
- Time Criticality: 9/10 (Valentine's Day promo needs this)
- Risk Reduction: 4/10 (moderate risk)
- Job Size: 5 story points

questions.question: Calculate WSJF score for each feature using formula: WSJF = (User-Business Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction) / Job Size

feedback.correct: Perfect! Promo Code (Z) has highest WSJF = 4.0 (high urgency, small size). Order Tracking (Y) = 2.5 (high risk/urgency). Loyalty Points (X) = 1.0 (large size, low urgency). Priority: Z → Y → X.
feedback.incorrect: WSJF prioritizes cost of delay (value + time criticality + risk reduction) divided by job size. Smaller, urgent, risky work ranks higher. Check your calculation: (Value + Time + Risk) / Size.

scenarios.title: Scenario 3: Kano Model - Basic vs Performance vs Delighters
description: Morgan analyzes customer feedback to categorize features by satisfaction impact:
Feature 1: Order Confirmation Email
Customer reaction if PRESENT: Neutral ('Of course I get a confirmation')
Customer reaction if ABSENT: Very dissatisfied ('How do I know my order went through?')
Feature 2: Faster Checkout (from 5 clicks to 2 clicks)
Customer reaction if PRESENT: Satisfied (scales with speed—more satisfaction)
Customer reaction if ABSENT: Somewhat dissatisfied (slower = less satisfaction)
Feature 3: Surprise Loyalty Bonus (unexpected 10% discount on 5th order)
Customer reaction if PRESENT: Delighted! ('Wow, I didn't expect this!')
Customer reaction if ABSENT: Neutral (they didn't expect it, so no disappointment)

questions.question: Categorize each feature using Kano Model:

basic.name: Basic Needs
basic.definition: Expected features—customers dissatisfied if absent, neutral if present

performance.name: Performance Needs
performance.definition: Satisfaction scales linearly—better performance = more satisfaction
performance.strategy: Prioritize based on ROI—optimize where it matters most

delighter.name: Delighters
delighter.definition: Unexpected features—customers delighted if present, neutral if absent

items.reasoning: Expected functionality—customers angry without it, neutral with it
Satisfaction scales with speed—2 clicks better than 5 clicks better than 10 clicks
Unexpected—customers delighted if present, don't miss it if absent

feedback.correct: Perfect Kano categorization! Basic Needs (confirmation email) are must-haves. Performance Needs (checkout speed) deliver linear ROI. Delighters (surprise bonus) create competitive advantage. Build Basics first, optimize Performance, add Delighters if budget allows.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: Basic Needs cause dissatisfaction if missing (but no extra satisfaction if present). Performance Needs scale linearly. Delighters create surprise value but aren't expected.

scenarios.title: Scenario 4: Risk vs Value Sequencing Decision
description: Sprint Planning. Two high-priority features compete for Sprint 1:
Option A: Payment Integration (HIGH RISK, HIGH VALUE)
- Value: 10/10 (can't launch without payment)
- Risk: 9/10 (third-party API integration, PCI compliance, never done before)
- Size: 13 story points
- Dependency: Blocks checkout, order processing
Option B: Menu Display (LOW RISK, HIGH VALUE)
- Value: 9/10 (core feature—customers browse menu)
- Risk: 2/10 (simple UI, team has done this before)
- Size: 8 story points
- Dependency: None

questions.question: Which feature should Morgan prioritize for Sprint 1, and why?

options.text: Option A (Payment Integration) - tackle high-risk work EARLY to learn, fail fast, and mitigate risk before launch
Option B (Menu Display) - deliver high-value, low-risk work FIRST to build momentum and show progress
Build both in parallel by splitting the team (half on A, half on B)
Defer both to Sprint 2 and focus on lower-priority features in Sprint 1

feedback.correct: Correct! Agile principle: Tackle high-risk work EARLY. Payment integration is risky (third-party API, PCI compliance). If it fails or takes 3 sprints instead of 1, you discover this in Sprint 1-3, not Sprint 11 (1 week before launch). Menu display is low-risk—can be done anytime.
feedback.incorrect: Think risk mitigation. If Payment Integration is risky (9/10) and takes longer than expected, when do you want to discover this? Sprint 1 (time to adapt) or Sprint 11 (crisis mode)? Agile prioritizes high-risk items EARLY to learn and adjust.

blocks.title: MoSCoW Method - Must, Should, Could, Won't

content.definition: MoSCoW is a prioritization technique that categorizes backlog items into 4 buckets based on criticality for a release.

categories.name: Must-have
categories.definition: Non-negotiable requirements—product can't launch without these
categories.example: Credit card payment, user login, product search

categories.name: Should-have
categories.definition: Important but not critical—product can launch with workarounds
categories.example: Email notifications, order history, wish list

categories.name: Could-have
categories.definition: Nice to have—add if time/budget allows
categories.example: Dark mode, social sharing, gift wrapping

categories.name: Won't-have (this time)
categories.definition: Explicitly deferred to future release—important for managing expectations
categories.example: Mobile app (defer to v2), analytics dashboard, A/B testing

benefits: Stakeholder alignment (clear what's in/out of scope)

blocks.title: WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First) - SAFe Framework

content.definition: WSJF prioritizes work by economic value. Formula: WSJF = Cost of Delay / Job Size

components.name: User-Business Value
components.question: How much value does this deliver to users/business?

components.name: Time Criticality
components.question: How urgent is this? (deadline, market window)

costOfDelay.formula: Cost of Delay = User-Business Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction

jobSize.note: Smaller jobs have higher WSJF (quick wins prioritized)

calculation.formula: WSJF = (User-Business Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction) / Job Size

example.interpretation: High WSJF = high priority. Delivers high value (7) with urgency (9) in small size (5 pts).

benefits: Prioritizes quick wins (high value, small size)

content.definition: Kano Model categorizes features by customer satisfaction impact. Different features have different satisfaction curves.

categories.name: Basic Needs (Must-Be Quality)
categories.satisfactionCurve: Dissatisfied if absent, NEUTRAL if present
categories.examples: Order confirmation email, shopping cart, checkout button
categories.curve: Flat when present (no extra satisfaction), steep decline when absent

categories.name: Performance Needs (One-Dimensional Quality)
categories.characteristics: Better = more satisfaction. Worse = less satisfaction.
categories.examples: Faster checkout (2 clicks better than 5), cheaper prices, more menu options
categories.strategy: Optimize based on ROI—invest where it matters most

categories.name: Delighters (Attractive Quality)
categories.satisfactionCurve: Delighted if present, NEUTRAL if absent
categories.examples: Free dessert on birthday, surprise loyalty bonus, personalized chef note
categories.curve: Steep increase when present, flat when absent (not missed)

applicationStrategy.phase1: Build ALL Basic Needs first (launch blockers)
applicationStrategy.phase2: Optimize key Performance Needs (checkout speed, search relevance)
applicationStrategy.phase3: Add Delighters if budget allows (competitive advantage)

content.insight: Over time, Delighters become Performance Needs, then Basic Needs. (E.g., free shipping was a delighter in 2005, now it's a basic expectation.)

blocks.title: Risk vs Value Sequencing - When to Tackle What

content.principle: Agile prioritizes HIGH-RISK work EARLY to learn, fail fast, and adapt. Don't save risky work for the end.

highValueHighRisk.rationale: Learn early. If it takes 3x longer than estimated, you discover this with time to adapt.

highValueLowRisk.rationale: Deliver reliably. Build on foundation from risky work.

lowValueHighRisk.rationale: High risk for low reward. Consider deferring or descoping.
lowValueHighRisk.example: Advanced analytics with uncertain ML models

lowValueLowRisk.rationale: Easy but not valuable. Build if time allows.

content.insight: Traditional projects save risky work for the end (waterfall). Agile does the opposite—tackle risk EARLY when you have time to adapt.

correct.text: Perfect MoSCoW! Must-haves = 38 pts (payment, search, order history). Should-haves = 8 pts (dietary filter, dark mode). I can defend this to Carlos: 'We're building all Must-haves and 2 Should-haves. Social sharing is deferred to v2.'

incorrect.text: Wait, you marked Social Sharing as Must-have? We've never launched without that feature before... oh wait, yes we have. It's nice marketing, but customers can order without it.

correct.text: WSJF gave me data to defend priorities! Promo Code (WSJF=4.0) is urgent + small. Order Tracking (WSJF=2.5) is risky + urgent. Loyalty Points (WSJF=1.0) is large + not urgent. Carlos accepted this because it's math, not opinion.

incorrect.text: Check your WSJF calculation. You're prioritizing large, non-urgent work over small, urgent work. WSJF = (Value + Time + Risk) / Size. Smaller, urgent jobs rank higher.

correct.text: Kano Model clarified our strategy! Build Basic Needs first (confirmation email—expected). Optimize Performance Needs (checkout speed—linear ROI). Add Delighters (surprise bonus—competitive edge) if budget allows.

incorrect.text: You're treating a Basic Need like a Delighter. Confirmation email isn't a 'nice surprise'—customers EXPECT it. If it's missing, they're dissatisfied (not neutral).

correct.text: Exactly! Payment Integration is high-risk (9/10). If we build it in Sprint 1 and it takes 3 sprints instead of 1, we discover this early with 10 sprints remaining. If we wait until Sprint 10, we're in crisis mode.

incorrect.text: We're saving the risky payment work for Sprint 11? That's a recipe for disaster. If it takes longer than expected or fails integration tests, we'll miss launch. Tackle risk EARLY.

screens.title: Prioritization Mastery
screens.summary: You've mastered three prioritization frameworks: MoSCoW (Must/Should/Could/Won't), WSJF (value + urgency + risk / size), and Kano Model (Basic/Performance/Delighters). You know when to tackle high-risk work early vs high-value work late.
takeaways: MoSCoW Method: Categorize backlog into Must (60%), Should (20%), Could (10%), Won't (10%) based on launch criticality
WSJF Formula: (User-Business Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction) / Job Size—prioritizes quick wins with high urgency
Kano Model: Basic Needs (expected—dissatisfied if absent), Performance Needs (linear satisfaction), Delighters (surprise value)
Agile prioritizes HIGH-RISK work EARLY to learn and adapt (not save risky work for the end like waterfall)
Backlog refinement sessions break down epics, clarify requirements, and update estimates collaboratively
Prioritization is data-driven (frameworks), not opinion-based ('I think this is important')
Balance value delivery, risk mitigation, and technical dependencies when sequencing work
Won't-have category is critical for managing stakeholder expectations and preventing scope creep

characterClosing.text: Before learning these frameworks, I prioritized based on whoever yelled loudest. Now I use MoSCoW for scope clarity, WSJF for data-driven ranking, and Kano for customer satisfaction strategy. Carlos can't argue with math.
